Begin by creating a new coordinate system with the following parameters: - Euler Angles: (-90.0, 0.0, -90.0) - Translation Vector: (0.0, 0.0, 0.0) Sketch: Create face_1 Face_1 contains two loops (loop_1 and loop_2) with their respective lines: Loop_1 1. line_1: (0.0, 0.0) → (0.0104, 0.0) 2. line_2: (0.0104, 0.0) → (0.0104, 0.0104) 3. line_3: (0.0104, 0.0104) → (0.0, 0.0104) 4. line_4: (0.0, 0.0104) → (0.0, 0.0) Loop_2 1. line_1: (0.0007, 0.0007) → (0.0098, 0.0007) 2. line_2: (0.0098, 0.0007) → (0.0098, 0.0098) 3. line_3: (0.0098, 0.0098) → (0.0007, 0.0098) 4. line_4: (0.0007, 0.0098) → (0.0007, 0.0007) Close each loop and apply appropriate constraints. Extrusion: Generate 3D Model After creating the sketch, generate a 3D model by extruding the sketch along the normal direction with the following parameters: - extrude_depth_towards_normal: 0.75 - extrude_depth_opposite_normal: 0.0 - sketch_scale: 0.0104 - Apply the "NewBodyFeatureOperation" operation. Description The dimensions of the final shape and the intermediate part are: - Height: 0.0104 m - Width: 0.0104 m - Length: 0.75 m Shape: A long, thin, cylindrical object with a slightly tapered end. Your parametric CAD model is now complete with all the necessary details about curves, loops, and faces. Ensure that the junior CAD designer follows your instructions to build the accurate 3D model.</description>

Then, sketch line 3 from point [0.0926, 0.3519] to point [0.0, 0.3519] and finally, sketch line 4 from point [0.0, 0.3519] to point [0.0, 0.2778]. Scaling and Extruding Sketch Scale the sketches by a factor of 0.75. Then, extrude both sketches along the Z-axis of the coordinate system by 0.0222 units. The resulting solid will have the desired dimensions for part 1.</description>
